title-group.article-title: Fabrication of TiC and ZrC reinforced Al-4 wt%Cu composite droplets using impulse atomization

article-meta.aff: 1Advanced Technology Education, Research and Application Center, Mersin University, Ciftlikkoy Campus, Mersin, Turkey
2Department of Chemical and Materials Engineering, University of Alberta, Edmonton, Alberta, Canada
3Particulate Materials Laboratories, Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering, Istanbul Technical University, Maslak, Istanbul, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Hülya Kaftelen, Advanced Technology Education, Research and Application Center, Mersin University, Ciftlikkoy Campus, 33343 Mersin, Turkey. Email: hkafdelen@mersin.edu.tr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this study, Al-4 wt%Cu alloy and its composites reinforced with different initial particle sizes of ZrC (8 µm and 157 µm) and TiC (13 µm and 93 µm) were fabricated by impulse atomization, and the microstructure of composite and unreinforced alloy droplets were examined by scanning electron microscopy, x-ray diffraction and cell size analyses. Scanning electron microscopic observations of composite droplets indicated that fine ZrC particles (8 µm) were mostly clustered while the other composites of the present investigation were distributed rather uniformly within the fine microstructure of droplets. The relationship between the cell size and the amount of carbide particles reveals that the presence of carbide particles in the alloy powders yields a finer structure. This could be due to the role of the carbide particles as heterogeneous sites for nucleation and to some extent due to particle restricted growth of matrix cells during solidification.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recently, several processing techniques are utilized in the fabrication of metal matrix composite (MMC) powders. These are conventional powder metallurgy (PM), spray forming and centrifugal atomization processes.1–4 MMC powders fabricated using mechanical alloying processes suffer from problems associated with powder contamination which have detrimental effects on resultant mechanical properties.4 In addition, high cost and large number of processing parameters such as milling time, speed, milling media, etc. involved in the PM process restrict the applications of MMC powders in critical areas.5 Spray forming is another process to produce MMC powders involving molten metal with particle injection.6–9 Microstructural properties of spray-formed TiC and SiC-reinforced Al composite powders were investigated by Yang et al.7 and Srivastava and Ojha,10 respectively, in regards to particle volume fraction and size. Although spray forming process overcomes segregation of carbide particles and reduces the interfacial reactions between the molten metal and ceramic particles due to short contact time, particles are not strongly bonded to molten metal due to inefficient particle feeding conditions.9 For instance, Srivastava and Ojha10 revealed small size SiC particles (6 µm) incorporated in droplets prior to their solidification, but large size SiC particles (45 µm) remained on the surface of droplets due to different velocities of droplets regarding that of SiC particles in the spray. Eslamian et al.11 fabricated 6061 Al-SiC composite powders using centrifugal atomization in order to solve particle engulfment and uneven distribution problems governed by spray deposition process. In their work, a wide variety of particle morphologies (irregular, oval like, ligament, etc.) were obtained after fabrication. The spherical morphology of spray deposited Al-7Si-SiC was observed for a limited size range (up to 100 µm) along with non-preferential distribution of SiC particles, whereas the morphology of powders greater than 100 µm in diameter deviated from spherical morphology having preferential distribution of SiC particles.8 However, spherical morphology of powders and homogeneous distribution of ceramic particles in the matrix are important factors affecting mechanical and physical properties of bulk composites. By utilizing impulse atomization, it is possible to overcome some processing difficulties such as the incorporation of carbide particulates and contamination problems of composite powders.12,13 Composite droplets with spherical morphologies can be fabricated via impulse atomization which has not yet been achieved by using centrifugal atomization.11

Impulse atomization, which was patented by Yuan et al.,14 offers many advantages including: (a) the production of spherical powders within a desirable size range, (b) providing a fine microstructure (cell or dendritic arm spacing) compared to the droplets of the same size range produced by other atomization techniques, (c) during melting the contact time between melt and ceramic can be minimized in order to reduce interfacial reactions. Up to now this technique has been successfully applied to a wide range of materials such as Al–Cu, Al–Fe–Ni, Mg alloy and tool steels.12,13,15 This process also offers unique opportunity to perform fundamental investigations of solidification processing due to controlled droplet production, small droplet sizes and reproducible thermal history.12 Studies on the fabrication of composite powders using an atomization technique and the effect of particle size on microstructural features of powders are quite scarce. Therefore, the intent of this work is to produce Al-4 wt% Cu alloy and its composites reinforced with TiC (average size of 13 µm, 93 µm) and ZrC (average size of 8 µm, 157 µm) particulates using novel atomization process to yield spherical shapes with uniform distributed carbide particles which otherwise hardly possible by other techniques. Besides, the development of microstructure including cell size and resultant distribution of TiC and ZrC particles were evaluated.

sec.title: Experimental procedure
sec.p: The starting materials used in the atomization process were Al-4 wt%Cu cast composites reinforced nominally with 10 wt% (5.87 vol.%) TiC and 10 wt% (4.37 vol.%) ZrC particles. The mean sizes of TiC particles used were 13 µm and 93 µm (both of them have 99.9% purity, supplied by Atlantic Equipment Engineering, AEE). The mean sizes of ZrC particles used were 8 µm (99.5% purity, supplied by Alfa Aesar) and 157µm (99.8% purity, supplied by Atlantic Equipment Engineering, AEE). In this study, different atomization experiments were carried out constitute the following compositions: Al-4 wt% Cu, Al-4 wt%Cu-TiC (13 µm), and Al-4 wt%Cu-TiC (93 µm), Al4Cu-ZrC (8 µm) and Al4Cu-ZrC (157 µm), hereafter referred to as Al4Cu, Al4Cu/TiC-13, Al4Cu/TiC-93, Al4Cu/ZrC-8 and Al4Cu/ZrC-157, respectively. The Al4Cu/ZrC-8 composite ingots were atomized using two different impulse temperatures (i.e., at 700°C and 840°C). For convenience, powder atomized using high superheat (SPH) temperature of 840°C is designated as Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH. Al ingot (99.8% purity), and copper wire (99.5% purity) were melted in graphite crucibles and heated to 800°C in a lab-scale induction furnace. Carbide particulates were incorporated in the molten Al-4 wt% Cu metal matrix with the aid of a K-Al-F flux (supplied from London and Scandinavian Metallurgical Co. Limited). This flux removes the oxide layer from the surface of the Al melts and improves the wetting properties even at low temperatures (below 900°C).2 After casting, ingots were cut from mid, up and bottom sections for optical examination. Preliminary results taken from these parts of cast samples indicated that the overall macroscopic distribution of carbide particles is quite homogeneous. In addition, during casting experiments any collapsed carbide particles on the bottom of graphite crucible were not observed. In our published work,16 using the same flux for the cast Al4Cu-TiC (5, 10, 15 and 20 vol.%) composites, only 1–3.5 vol.% of TiC particles were lost during casting process. Therefore, it was assumed that almost 10 wt% of carbide particles (TiC and ZrC) were incorporated into cast samples. These cast composites were used as feed-stocks for melting in impulse atomization (IA) experiments.

During IA process, using an induction furnace, about 300 g of composite ingots were melted in a graphite crucible containing a graphite nozzle plate with 37 orifices. Prior to melting, the gas atmosphere in the atomizer was kept to less than 80 ppm oxygen and the atomization tower was operated with a small atmospheric overpressure of helium. Table 1 summarizes the experimental parameters for each atomization run. Before an atomization run was initiated, the inductively stirred melt was kept at this temperature for 5 min to ensure complete homogenization. The low frequency impulses were applied using an alumina plunger to push the molten metal through the nozzle orifices which generated a discontinuous stream of molten metal on the bottom of the crucible. The atomized powders were collected in an oil bath after falling 1 m in free fall through a stagnant gas atmosphere. The schematic sketch of Impulse Atomization (IA) unit is shown in Figure 1. Following each run, the powders were cleaned, dried and sieved according to MPIF standards.17 The sieving results were analyzed using log-normal analysis to yield a mass median size (d50) and a geometric standard deviation (GSD, d84/d50).17 The median sizes of the impulse atomized (IA) droplets with geometric standard deviations (GSD, d84/d50) obtained from log-normal plot of atomized powders are listed in Table 1. Figure 1.
Schematic representation of IA tower. IA: impulse atomization.
Table 1.
Impulse atomization parameters of atomized droplets
Compositions Nozzle size (µm)/No. of holes Atm/T (oC) d50,GSD (µm, d50/d84)
Al4Cu 350/37 He/700 651 (1.46)
Al4Cu/ZrC-8 350/37 He/700 475 (1.44)
Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH 413/37 He/840 475 (1.37)
Al4Cu/ZrC-157 413/37 He/700 592 (1.39)
Al4Cu/TiC-13 413/37 He/700 564 (1.42)
Al-4Cu/TiC-93 413/37 He/700 546 (1.30)

The cold mounted and metallographically polished IA powders were examined using a Hitachi S-2700™ Model scanning electron microscope (SEM). The cell spacing calculation was performed on the 2-D images of the composite samples. Cell spacing was counted manually from at least four lines of known length (l) on each micrograph using the random line intercept method.18 X-ray diffraction (XRD) experiments were carried out in a Rigaku™ Rotating anode XRD system using copper Kα radiation and a scan rate of 0.65°/s over the range of 0–90° of 2θ. In order to specify the carbide contents of atomized powders, carbon analysis has been carried out. Carbon analysis results obtained from hot combustion of atomized powders on Eltra™ CS 800 Carbon/Sulphur Analyzer. The actual volume fraction of carbide particles in atomized powders was calculated from the mass fraction of carbides using the experimental carbon content. Density values of mean sized atomized powders were measured with a Quantachrome™ Multipycnometer, which operated using ultra high purity He gas. The density results were analyzed using 10 runs for each sample to yield an average density and standard deviation.

sec.title: Sieve analysis results
sec.p: The mass median size (d50) of the impulse atomized (IA) droplets with geometric standard deviations (GSD, d84/d50) obtained are given in Table 1. According to Conlon et al.18 the median particle size of given IA powders is dependent upon such factors as alloy superheating, material, hole size of the nozzle plate, atomization gas (He, N2, etc.), oxygen level in the chamber, and the applied frequency. Depending on the composition, it is expected that the smaller nozzle size leads to the smaller mass median size of atomized powders.18 However, as can be seen in Table 1 that the median particle size of IA Al4Cu droplets is reduced from 651 µm for the Al4Cu alloy to 564 µm and 546 µm with addition of TiC particles in size of 13 µm and 93 µm, respectively. This has occurred despite the fact that Al4Cu alloy powders were produced using a smaller nozzle size of 350 µm compared to 413 µm for the TiC-reinforced composite powders. The presence of hard insoluble particles in composites increase the melt viscosity to a great extent, as reported by Lloyd19 who studied solidification behavior of Al/SiC composites and by Dutta and Surappa20 who investigated the microstructure of AlCu/SiC composites during solidification. Although Al4Cu alloy and Al4Cu/ZrC-8 powders were produced using the same nozzle size of 350 µm and atomization temperature (700°C), about 25% decrease in the mass median size (d50) was achieved with the addition of ZrC particles (Table 1). The addition of ZrC particles has similar effect on mass median size of powders with the addition of TiC particles into the Al-4 wt%Cu alloy droplets. The possible reason for a decrease in the median size of Al4Cu alloy composite powders is unclear since effects of carbide particles on viscosity of melt which directly affects the median size (d50) of droplets have not been investigated for the present alloy systems. The range of standard deviations are from 1.30 to 1.46 indicating that the distribution in size of IA powders is very narrow, considering the fact that the standard deviation of powders produced with other atomization devices is usually around 2.2.21

sec.title: Density measurements
sec.p:
Carbon analysis results obtained from hot combustion of atomized powders and the carbide contents (vol.%) of powders are given in Table 2. Table 2 also gives theoretical and measured density and estimated porosity values of atomized powders. The experimental density results were obtained from gas pycnometry measurements. Theoretical density ρth, values of atomized composites were calculated by using the rule of mixture. Volume fractions of carbides and matrix materials are the actual volume fractions given in Table 2. Note that density values of TiC and ZrC particles are 4.93 g/cm3 and 6.73 g/cm3,22 respectively, and the density value is 2.77 g/cm3 for Al4Cu. Table 2.
Actual weight percentage of carbon and volume percentage of carbide particles after atomization. Theoretical, measured and estimated porosity values of atomized powders
Compositions Actual wt% of carbon Actual vol.% of carbidea ρmeasured (g/cm3) ρtheoretical (g/cm3) Estimated porosity (%)
Al4Cu – – 2.762 ± 0.001 2.77 0.28
Al4Cu/ZrC-8 0.855 3.16 2.848 ± 0.002 2.895 1.63
Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH 0.566 2.06 2.852 ± 0.003 2.852 –
Al4Cu/ZrC-157 0.807 2.98 2.841 ± 0.009 2.888 1.62
Al4Cu/TiC-13 2.099 6.17 2.862 ± 0.007 2.903 1.41
Al4Cu/TiC-93 0.717 2.04 2.855 ± 0.001 2.814 –
a
Calculated from carbon analysis result.

The results listed in Table 2 show that the measured density values of IA composite powders (Al4Cu/TiC-13 and Al4Cu/TiC-93) are greater than that of the matrix Al4Cu alloy powders. This is attributed to the presence of TiC particles, which have a higher density (ρTiC = 4.93 g/cm3) than the density of Al (ρAl = 2.71 g/cm3).22 Similarly, ZrC particles, which have a high density (ρZrC = 6.56 g/cm3), contribute to the high density values of the IA samples. In addition, the measured densities revealed that the powders containing smaller TiC particles (13 µm) have a slightly higher measured density of 2.862 ± 0.07 g/cm3 compared to 2.855 ± 0.001 g/cm3 for Al4Cu/TiC-93 composite powders. The measured density of the Al4Cu/TiC-13 composite droplets correlates well with the higher amount of incorporated TiC particles (6.17vol.%) in the Al4Cu/TiC-13 sample. It is also apparent from Table 2 that the estimated porosity of all atomized powders is less than 2%.

sec.title: Microstructural characterization
sec.p:
Typical backscattered electron images (BEI) taken from the mass median size (d50) of the Al4Cu/TiC-13 and Al4Cu/TiC-93 composites droplets, produced by IA process are shown in Figure 2(a) and (c), respectively. It can be noted from these figures that almost all of the spherical powders of Al4Cu/TiC-13 are rich in TiC, whereas some of the IA Al4Cu/TiC-93 powders are deficient in TiC particles. TiC content determined by carbon analysis (Table 2) verifies the overall SEM/BEI micrograph of Al4Cu/TiC-93 composite powders (Figure 2(c)) which contain TiC particle-free droplets. A high magnification micrograph of the Al4Cu/TiC-13 composite (Figure 2(b)) reveals that TiC particles are uniformly distributed in spherical Al4Cu matrix alloy powders. It may be noted that fine TiC particles are distributed homogeneously within the Al4Cu droplet while the relatively coarse TiC particles in Al4Cu/TiC-13 (Figure 2(b)) and Al4Cu/TiC-93 (Figure 2(c)) composites are mostly located along the periphery of the particles. The high magnification image of the Al4Cu/TiC-93 composite droplet (Figure 2(d)) shows a TiC particle located in the center of the droplet, which was rarely observed in the overall images of this composite powder (Figure 2(c)). On the basis of SEM images of composite droplets, it is clear that no intermetallic phases exist in the interface between the particle and the matrix or within the matrix. Figure 2.
Overall and single droplet SEM images of the (a)–(b) Al4Cu/TiC-13, (c)–(d) Al4Cu/TiC-93 composite droplets.

Several studies23–25 are available in the literature concerning wetting behaviors of TiC particles by the molten Al. The results from the literature showed that the wetting of TiC is dependent on temperature, and alloy composition. For instance, good wetting for 2024 and 1010 Al alloys with contact angles of 60° at 900°C were reported by Leon et al.,23 who investigated the effect of alloying elements (Zn, Mg and Cu) on the wetting behavior of TiC by 1010, 2024, 6061 and 7075 Al alloys. Naidich26 reported that 95% of TiC particles incorporated into molten Al with a contact angle of 108° at 700°C. For the Al-4 wt%Cu/TiC system, the contact angles were measured by Contreras27 using the sessile drop method as follows: 86° at 800°C, 60° at 900°C and 45° at 1000°C. This shows a decrease in contact angle with increasing temperature, consequently indicating good wetting characteristics. However, Kennedy and Karantzalis2 stated that the contact angle measurements are not always an accurate way of predicting the incorporation of carbide particles due to the presence of an oxide layer on the melt. Therefore, in the present study, the wetting angle for both Al4Cu/TiC-13 and Al4Cu/TiC-93 composites is probably lower than the reported value of 108°26 at the temperature of 700°C, since atomization experiments were performed under controlled atmosphere conditions using high purity He and the oxygen level was kept less than 80 ppm. Additionally, the incorporation of TiC particles prior to atomization process using a K-Al-F flux helps avoid the issue of penetrating an oxide layer. Figure 2(b) and 2(d) also show the eutectic structure in the aluminum matrix which has a white color in the interdendritic regions.

A detailed SEM micrograph of the Al4Cu/TiC-13 droplet is shown in Figure 3(a), revealing remarkably homogeneous dispersion of fine TiC particles (13 µm) located preferentially in the interdendritic regions or the cell structure of the primary α-Al phase. The EDS analysis given in Figure 3(b) taken from the light appearing particles confirms that these particles belong to the TiC phase, while cell structure contains both the α-Al and Al2Cu phases as confirmed by the EDS spectra in Figure 3(c). As mentioned before, it should be noted that no interfacial reaction products such as Al4C3, Al3Ti, Ti3AlC, reported in several works,4,17 were observed at the TiC particle and matrix interfaces (Figure 3(a)) due to high temperature and high cooling rates utilized in IA process. The microstructures of the present composite droplets atomized at the quench distance of 1 m show the homogeneity in solidification cell structures. The complete absence of heterogeneity such as fine cell structures associated with coarse cells indicates that droplets in sizes between 500 and 600 µm (Table 1) were completely solidified prior to entering quench bath. Similar microstructural features were reported by Wiskel et al.28 for the AA6061 alloy droplets (less than 600 µm in size) quenched at 1.2 m. Figure 3.
High magnification SEM micrograph of the (a) Al4Cu/TiC-13 sample, (b)–(c) corresponding EDS analyses taken from TiC and Al2Cu, respectively. (The circled areas show the SiC contamination from grinding paper during polishing of the sample.).

The dark spots in Figure 3(a) represent the pores/or voids, which formed probably due to removal of TiC particulates from the surface of powders during metallographic surface preparation since shapes and sizes of porosities closely match with those of small carbide particles. During polishing of powder samples, SiC contamination from grinding papers were observed in the matrix and they were indicated as small white circles in Figure 3(a).

Preliminary SEM work on IA powders show that the spherical morphology with the similar distribution of ZrC particles was observed in each size range of droplets. Therefore, in this study only the droplets in the median size range (given in Table 1) was undertaken to investigate the resultant distribution of particles. Figure 4(a)–(f) are the SEM/BEI micrographs of the Al4Cu/ZrC-8, Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH and Al4Cu/ZrC-157 composite powders showing powder morphologies and distributions of carbide particles. Figure 4.
Overall and single droplet SEM images of the (a)–(b) Al4Cu/ZrC-8, (c)–(d) Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH, and (e)–(f) Al4Cu/ZrC-157 powders.

Figure 4(a), (c) and (e) show the overall morphologies of IA Al4Cu/ZrC-8, Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH and Al4Cu/ZrC-157 samples, respectively, and their single droplet images were given in Figure 4(b), (d) and (f), respectively. It can be noted from Figure 4 that almost all of the spherical droplets are rich in ZrC contents in the Al4Cu/ZrC-8 and Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH samples, while some of the atomized droplets are deficient of ZrC particles in the Al4Cu/ZrC-157 sample. This indicates that some coarse ZrC particles (157 µm) were not delivered through the nozzle plate due to their collapse around the nozzle plate. Based on the single droplet images of the composite powders in Figure 4, spherical ZrC particles with an average size of 8 µm were mostly clustered in Al4Cu/ZrC-8 and Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH samples but particles were distributed both in the exterior and interior regions of droplets. Particle clustering observed for Al4Cu/ZrC-8 and Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH composite samples was probably due to agglomeration of starting powder which did not dissociate during their incorporation into aluminum melt. However, coarse ZrC particles (157 µm) which are angularly shaped with varying aspect ratios, settled down generally towards to the periphery of Al4Cu/ZrC-157 powders (Figure 4(f)). Similar clustering phenomena was also reported in our previous work29 for 8 µm ZrC (10 wt%) particle reinforced Al-4 wt% Cu composite sample produced by ball milling and sintering.

In liquid metallurgy processes, non-uniform distribution of reinforcement particles in the matrix is generated by either a relatively low solid–liquid interface velocity associated with slow cooling rate of the melt and/or poor wettability of melt with ceramic particles.10 Russell et al.30 reported that more than 95% of ZrC particles could be incorporated in Al matrix with the contact angle of 150° at 900°C. In the present investigation, the wetting angle is probably lower than the reported value of 150° at the temperature of 900°C.30 The reason is that the atomization experiments were performed under controlled atmosphere conditions using high purity He and the oxygen level was kept less than 20 ppm, as mentioned before. Considerably different microstructures were clearly observed in Figure 4(b) and (d), even though the Al4Cu/ZrC-8 and Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH powder samples contain the same average size of ZrC particles (8 µm). In addition to the carbide particles, rectangular shaped particles are present in the Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH sample produced by higher superheat temperature (840°C) compared to that (700°C) of other droplets. Besides, very fine carbide particles (≤ 1.5 µm) which are lower than the initial size of ZrC (8 µm) were observed in the Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH sample (Figure 4(d)), indicating that some of the agglomerated carbide particles were broken up during impulse utilized with relatively high superheat temperature. Furthermore, the appearance of big dark spots in the SEM micrographs of the Al4Cu/ZrC-8 and Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH samples (Figure 4(a) and (c)) might be due to an over-etching of the polished powder surface. In addition to carbide particles, Al2Cu network (cell) structures can also be observed in the microstructure of droplets, in Figure 4.

A high magnification SEM/BEI micrograph of the Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH composite powders (Figure 5(a)) revealed that the microstructure consists of small-scale clustered ZrC particles and the light gray plate-like shape particles (indicated by arrows) corresponding to Al3Zr particles. The well-distributed white particles in Figure 5(a) are ZrC particles based on the EDS analysis, which is given in Figure 5(b). It can be noted that the presence of small porosities (dark points in Figure 5(a)) is likely due to the removal of ZrC particles from the surfaces of powders during metallographic surface preparation. The EDS analysis in Figure 5(c) revealed that Al3Zr particles consist of about 75.9 at.% Al, and 23.31 at.% Zr, indicating the atomic ratio of Al to Zr is about 1:3. Figure 5.
Typical SEM images of the (a) Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH sample fabricated using a high superheat temperature, and (b)–(c) corresponding EDS analyses taken from ZrC and Al3Zr particles, respectively.

Figure 6 shows the XRD pattern of the Al4Cu matrix alloy and Al4Cu/TiC-13 and Al4Cu/TiC-93 droplets. Characteristic peaks of the Al phase (fcc Bravais lattice, Fm3m space group, a = 0.40494 nm),31 and the Al2Cu phase (bct Bravais lattice, I4 space group, a = 0.5070 nm and c = 0.4890 nm)32 are present in all powder samples. Additionally, TiC peaks (fcc Bravais lattice with lattice parameter a = 0.43274 nm)33 were identified in the Al4Cu/TiC-13 sample (Figure 6(b)), whereas no peaks belonging to TiC phase could be observed in the Al4Cu/TiC-93 powder sample (Figure 6(a)). The absence of TiC peaks in the X-ray diffraction pattern of the atomized Al4Cu/TiC-93 powders (Figure 6(a)) is presumably due to low volume fraction (< 2 vol.%) of TiC in the matrix after atomization. The actual TiC content of 2.04 vol.% (Table 2) in the Al4Cu/TiC-93 sample is very close to the detection limit of the XRD instrument (∼2 vol.%) indicating that TiC in the Al4Cu matrix could not be easily identified by XRD. Figure 6.
XRD patterns of the IA droplets: (a) Al4Cu/TiC-93, (b) Al4Cu/TiC-13, and (c) Al4Cu.

Figure 7(a) and (b) show the XRD patterns of Al4Cu/ZrC- 157 and Al4Cu/ZrC-8 composite powders, respectively, fabricated by IA process. Additionally, XRD pattern of Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH composite powders atomized at 840°C is given in Figure 7(c). Diffraction peaks belonging to Al, Al2Cu and ZrC (fcc Bravais lattice, Fm3m space group, a = 0.4693 nm)34 were identified in all composite powders (Figure 7(a) to (c)). Furthermore, as seen from Figure 7(a) and (b), XRD peak intensities of ZrC phase in Al4Cu/ZrC-8 composite powders are higher than that in the Al4Cu/ZrC-157 powders due to large number of carbide particles present in the Al4Cu/ZrC-8 composite droplets after IA process. A small reflections of the Al3Zr phase (tetragonal Bravais lattice, I4/mmm space group, a = 4.009 nm and c = 17.281 nm)35 are present in the XRD patterns of the Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH composite powders (Figure 7(c)). The reason for the existence of the Al3Zr intermetallic phase after atomization is associated with the relatively higher superheat (SPH) temperature (840°C) which leads to dissolution of ZrC particles. Figure 7.
XRD patterns of the atomized droplets: (a) Al4Cu/ZrC-157, (b) Al4Cu/ZrC-8, and (c) Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH.

It is worth noting from Figure 7(a) that the intensities of the ZrC peaks in the Al4Cu/ZrC-157 sample are lower than those observed in the XRD scans of the Al4Cu/ZrC-8 composite powders containing smaller ZrC particles (8 µm), revealing the low content of incorporated ZrC particles in Al4Cu/ZrC-157 composite powders. As seen in Table 2, ZrC contents of atomized powders were determined to be 2.98 vol.% for Al4Cu/ZrC-157 powders and 3.16 vol.% for Al4Cu/ZrC-8. The relatively low volume content of ZrC particles in Al4Cu/ZrC-157 composite powders correlates with low intensity of ZrC peaks in the XRD patterns in Figure 7(a).

Furthermore, the resultant carbide content (Table 2) of each sample is less than the initial weight percentage (10 wt%) of both TiC and ZrC particles, indicating that some of the carbide particles added to the pre-alloyed ingots did not end up in the MMC powders. Although this may be due to these particles settling around the nozzle plate in the atomizing crucible, sufficient amounts of carbides are present for this study. The differences in volume fractions of both fine TiC and ZrC particles are noted due to high incorporated amount of TiC (13 µm) particles compared to ZrC (8 µm) particles (Table 2). In addition, ZrC particles show poor wettability with Al alloy compared to TiC particles and this leads to clustering of ZrC carbide particles prior to solidification. Kennedy and Karantzalis2 reported that the particle incorporation is dependent on the inherent particle-liquid wetting behavior. In general, the Al-TiC system is characterized by good wettability, low contact angles and good interfacial bonding.1 This is confirmed by the work of Kennedy and Karantzalis,2 who reported that the ZrC particles were clustered, whereas TiC particles were uniformly distributed. Therefore, in the present study the differences in incorporated amount of carbide particles are most probably due to their wetting behavior.

As stated previously, a relatively high superheat temperature (840°C) leads to formation of the Al3Zr phase in the present composite droplets. The formation reaction of Al3Zr at 1100 K (827°C) is expressed as: (1)13Al+3ZrC=3Al3Zr+Al4C3

The standard free energy change (ΔG°) of this reaction at 840°C was calculated on the basis of the thermodynamic free energy formation data of products and reactants in equation (1) available in the literature.36,37 The ΔG° was calculated to be less than −140 kJ at 840°C. This indicates that the reaction is possible thermodynamically at the studied temperature of 840°C. Kennedy and Karantzalis2 pointed out that the reactivity of ceramic particles with molten metal cannot always be predicted from the heat of formation energy for metal carbides. Their comparative results between TiC and ZrC with molten Al indicated that Al3Zr intermetallic phase occurred at the temperature of 900°C38 although the heat of formation energy (ΔHf,298 = −207 kJ/mol) of ZrC is higher than that of TiC (ΔHf,298 = −185 kJ/mol) which does not dissolve.2 Similarly, the formations of Al3Zr phases were reported by Zhang et al.39 who produced an Al-Al3Zr composite by in-situ reaction of the Al with a 20 wt% K2ZrF6-KBF4 flux at 1173 K close to the present IA temperature and by Azevedo and Santos40 who synthesized the Al3Zr particles from Al/(5–20 wt%)ZrO2 via reactive hot pressing at 1073 K. In the present study, these particles are basically rectangular in shape and non-uniform in size. The morphology of Al3Zr particles is very similar to those revealed in the Azevedo and Santos’s work40 and in the work of Kobashi et al.41 who identified the Al3Zr intermetallic by EPMA analysis in cast Al/ZrC composites.

Based on the Al-Zr phase diagram,42 Zr has a low solubility in aluminum and it precipitates out at the atomization temperature of 840°C in the form of metastable L1 Al3Zr particles. It was reported by Robson43 that presence of copper in alloy composition accelerates the precipitation kinetics of the L12 Al3Zr phase and this phase is resistant to dissolution and coarsening. According to equation (1), the Al4C3 should be present in the microstructure of the Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH sample, but both XRD and SEM/EDS determinations did not reveal the presence of Al4C3 phase (Figures 5 and 7). This was probably due to small amount of Al4C3 particles as well as the removal of Al4C3 throughout metallographic preparation.44 Therefore, in order to identify the presence of Al4C3 particles, ZrC particles as well as the reaction products were extracted from Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH sample by dissolving the Al matrix using a dilute hydrochloric acid (30 vol.%) solution. The cleaning of the extracted particles was conducted using an acetone solvent rinse. The filtrated particles were dried, then were examined using the XRD investigation. Figure 8 shows the XRD diffraction of the extracted particles from Al4Cu/ZrC-SPH composite which indicated the presence of ZrC, Al3Zr, Cu (fcc Bravais lattice, a = b = c = 0.3615 nm)45 and Al(OH)3 (primitive monoclinic Bravais lattice, a = 0.8624 nm, b = 0.5060 nm and c = 0.9700 nm)46 phases, but no Al4C3. Different from the observed phases in Figure 7(c), the presence of Cu and Al(OH)3 most probably due to the degradation of Al2Cu and Al4C3 phases, respectively. Due to its hydrophilic nature, Al4C3 phase is unstable in environments such as water, methanol, HCl, etc.47–49 Al(OH)3 phase is most probably occurring when the Al4C3 phase is exposed to dilute HCl solution during the extraction process. Similarly, the formation of Al(OH)3 due to the dissolution of Al4C3 phase was reported by Park and Lucas47 who studied interfacial Al4C3 phase in the cast 6061 Al/SiCp composite and by Reyes et. al.50 who fabricated SiC-reinforced Al–Si–Mg matrix composite. Figure 8.
XRD pattern of extracted particles from Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH composite sample.

sec.title: Cell spacing measurements
sec.p:
Bower et al.51 stated that the degree of microstructural refinement achieved during solidification is often evaluated by measuring cell spacing. The values of cell size, λ, for the studied composite powders are given in Table 3. The cell size value for unreinforced Al4Cu powders was measured as 9.34 ± 0.51 µm from the droplet size of 431 ± 4.2 µm. Almost similar cell size value of 9.45 ± 0.34 µm for the droplet size of 463 µm was reported by Wiskel et al.52 for Al-4.3 wt% Cu atomized at 715°C using He. Table 3.
Calculated cell size and estimated cooling rates of IA powders
Compositions Average diameter (µm) Cell size (µm) Cooling rate (K/s)
Al4Cu 431 ± 4.2 9.34 ± 0.51 154
Al4Cu/ZrC-8 354 ± 6.4 6.05 ± 0.42 568
Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH 420 ± 5.2 9.83 ± 0.66 132
Al4Cu/ZrC-157 466 ± 8.7 8.23 ± 0.30 225
Al4Cu/TiC-13 456 ± 5.3 6.98 ± 0.70 390
Al4Cu/TiC-93 422 ± 9.8 9.19 ± 0.63 169

Some researchers53,54 reported that the TiC particles in Al/TiC composites have a coherent interface with α-Al and thus these particles act as heterogeneous nucleation sites for the formation of α-Al crystals. In the present study, the higher volume fraction of TiC particles (Table 2) in the Al4Cu/TiC-13 than those in the Al4Cu/TiC-93 would yield a much higher surface area of TiC in the molten atomized droplets. Thus there are a greater number of heterogeneous nucleation sites in Al4Cu/TiC-13 than in Al4Cu/TiC-93 at the start of solidification. Hence, it is yielding a finer structure.

Figure 9 shows the relationship between cell size and vol.% of carbide particles present in the atomized powders. Note that the volume percentage of carbide particles and their cell size values are taken from Tables 2 and 3, respectively. As seen in Figure 9, Al4Cu/TiC-13 composite powders have more carbide particles in each of the droplets compared to powders containing coarse carbide particles, i.e., Al4Cu/TiC-93 and Al4Cu/ZrC-157. Therefore, the cell size values and hence the cooling rates of the Al4Cu/TiC-93 and Al4Cu/ZrC-157 composites (Table 3) approach to those of the Al4Cu sample which does not include carbide particles. In case of Al4Cu/ZrC-8 and Al4Cu/ZrC-8 SPH systems, the presence of ZrC particle clusters proved that changes in cooling rate (Table 3) seem to have not much effect on the distribution of ZrC (8 µm) particles, thus these particles are not so prominent effect on cell size refinement. Therefore, this figure does not show the data for Al4Cu/ZrC-8 and Al4Cu/ZrC-8 SPH samples, due to presence of clustering of ZrC particles in these samples. Also included in Figure 9 are cell size measurements for the Al-4.5% Cu droplets gas atomized in helium atmosphere as a function of droplet size taken from Table VII (run # 980821) in Wiskel et al.’s work.52 Note that the open symbols represent the droplet size values whereas the closed symbols belong to the vol.% of carbide particles. At droplet in size of 400 µm values, the cell size for Al-4Cu matrix alloy measured in the present study falls on the same data as the cell size measured by Wiskel et al.52 In addition, for roughly the same size of particle (400 µm), the cell spacing decreases as a function of vol.% of carbide particles, thus refining the cell size. This could be due to the role of the carbide particles as heterogeneous sites for nucleation and to some extent due to particle restricted growth of matrix cells during solidification. However, the present data do not presently differentiate between type of carbides (TiC or ZrC) or their size. Therefore, more detailed experiments would be required to investigate the effects of carbide type and size. Figure 9.
Effects of volume of carbide particles on the cell size of droplets. The y2 axis indicates the droplet size from our data and the data of Wiskel et al.52 The data of Wiskel et al.52 is indicated as symbol (▵). The symbols for vol.% of carbide particles of Al4Cu (•), Al4Cu/TiC-13 (♦), Al4Cu/TiC-93 (★), Al4Cu/ZrC-157 (▾). Note that open symbols are belonging to the droplet size data.

As mentioned above, based on SEM images and the XRD analysis, some of the droplets in the Al4Cu/ZrC-157 and Al4Cu/TiC-93 composites do not contain carbide particles due to low content of carbide particles in each powder particle. Therefore, the amount of carbide particles in the droplets verifies the XRD analysis and SEM images of these atomized powders. When comparing the Al4Cu/TiC-13 and the Al4Cu/TiC-93 powders having almost the same atomized size droplets (Table 3), presence of high number of carbide particles in each of the Al4Cu/TiC-13 droplets yield to small cell size.

It is well known that the fineness of a structure (cell spacing, λ) is inversely proportional to the heat extraction during solidification process and this relation can be expressed: λ=Bɛ-n.55 In this relation, ɛ is cooling rate, B is the pre-exponential constant and n is the exponential power whose value depends on the alloy. Using this relation, the cooling rates of IA powders can be calculated and are presented in Table 3. Note that the values of B and ɛ are taken as 50 µm (Ks−1)n and 0.333, respectively.56 A considerable increase of the cooling rate exponents of the Al-Cu/SiC and A356 Al/SiC composites were also reported by Dutta20 and by Rohatgi et al.,57 respectively, while Mannikar58 reported a decrease in the exponent of A356 Al reinforced with SiC particles. Even though some contradictory works has been reported,20,57,58 it can be concluded from the present results that the amount of TiC particles in the present droplets has influenced the cooling rate of aluminum matrix alloy.59

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The Al-4 wt%Cu composites containing 10 wt% ZrC (with average particulate size of 8 µm and 157 µm) and TiC (with average particulate size of 13 µm and 93 µm) reinforced composites were fabricated by IA process, and the microstructure of composite and unreinforced alloy droplets were examined by SEM, XRD and sieve analysis. According to these analyses, the following conclusions can be drawn as:
Fabrication of spherical Al-4 wt% Cu composite droplets including 8 µm and 157 µm ZrC and 13 µm and 93 µm TiC particles were successfully achieved using the impulse atomization process.
The composite droplets including coarse TiC particles and ZrC particles seem to be mostly particle free compared to the droplets containing the smaller TiC and ZrC particles. The microstructure of composite droplets revealed that fine ZrC (8 µm) particles are clustered and non-uniformly distributed in both the interior and the exterior regions of droplets.
The decreased reinforcement particle size and number of incorporated carbide particles can be attributed to relatively uniform distribution of TiC particles and small cell size within the Al-4 wt% Cu matrix alloy. Therefore, it can be concluded that microstructural features including the carbide distribution and cell size refinement depend on incorporated amount of carbide particles after atomization.
The XRD results showed that Al4Cu/TiC composite droplets consist of Al, Al2Cu and TiC and Al4Cu/ZrC droplets consist of Al, Al2Cu and ZrC phases. In addition, the Al3Zr phase in the composite droplet fabricated by relatively high superheat temperature (840°C) was identified whereas the Al4C3 phase was not identified in the sample after atomization. However, the presence of the Al(OH)3 phase in the extracted Al4Cu/ZrC-8-SPH sample indicates that this phase results from the Al4C3 phase exposed to the moist environment.

One of the authors (H. Kaftelen) gratefully acknowledges the Scientific and Research Council of Turkey (TÜBİTAK) for support through the International Research Fellowship and to the Natural Science and Engineering Research Council of Canada.

ack.p: The authors wish to thank Assoc. The authors also wish to thank the group members of Advanced Materials Processing Lab in U of A, especially Dr Arash Ilbagi, Mr Class Knoop for helping in atomization experiments.

sec.p: None declared.
